title: Circuits - draw diagram for two resistive heaters

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.A circuit within a home is designed so that two electric water heaters can be operated independently. Each heater can be turned on and off without affecting the function of the other heater.(a) The symbols shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> represent the components, in addition to wires, that are part of the circuit: a source of <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math>, two switches, and the two heaters. The heaters are modeled as resistors. In the following space, draw a circuit diagram connecting the circuit elements so thatboth heaters operate when both switches are closed,neither heater operates when both switches are open, ANDeach heater can operate by itself when one switch is closed and one switch is open.

The parts within the question may not have equal weight.A circuit within a home is designed so that two electric water heaters can be operated independently. Each heater can be turned on and off without affecting the function of the other heater.(a) The symbols shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> represent the components, in addition to wires, that are part of the circuit: a source of <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math>, two switches, and the two heaters. The heaters are modeled as resistors. In the following space, draw a circuit diagram connecting the circuit elements so thatboth heaters operate when both switches are closed,neither heater operates when both switches are open, ANDeach heater can operate by itself when one switch is closed and one switch is open.

(b) The <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> of the source is <math alttext="uppercase script E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>, and the heaters have resistances of <math alttext="R sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Derive an equation for the energy <math alttext="E sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>S</mi></msub></math> produced by the <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> source in a time interval <math alttext="delta t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></math> if both heaters are switched on. Express your equation for <math alttext="E sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>S</mi></msub></math> in terms of <math alttext="uppercase script E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>, <math alttext="R sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="delta t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

Engineers are designing a new heater system that is to include both a power supply and a single resistive heating element. The power supply will apply a potential difference <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> to the heater. <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> will be constant in the final design, but could be anywhere in the range <math alttext="delta V sub 0 less than or equal to delta V, less than or equal to 3 delta V sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>≤</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, where <math alttext="delta V sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> is the minimum potential difference that is practical to use. The engineers want to know what the heater resistance should be for any potential difference value under consideration in order to dissipate a certain amount of power <math alttext="P sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> in the heater.(c)i. On the axes in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, sketch a graph of heater resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> as a function of potential difference <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math>, where the same amount of power <math alttext="P sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> would be dissipated by the heater at every value of potential difference over the range shown. Clearly label the curve or line you draw “<math alttext="P sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>.”

ii. On the same axes, sketch a similar graph, this time for a heater power that is greater than <math alttext="P sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Clearly label this curve or line “Greater Power.”

The engineers decide to add a nonideal ammeter to the design of the heater system. The ammeter will measure the current in the heating element.(d) If the heating element must still dissipate a power of <math alttext="P sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, indicate how would the curve or line labeled “<math alttext="P sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>” in part (c)(i) be affected, if at all. If there is no effect on the graph, say so explicitly. Justify your answer.Note: Assume that <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> is the potential difference of the power supply, which may or may not be equal to the potential difference across the heating element when the ammeter is present in the circuit.
